bow: tear during first delivery what to do with second text wall sorry hi there ve never posted in this subreddit before but it seems like the place to ask this we are planning to have second baby soon and while it may seem to be jumping the gun little given that not even pregnant yet this is something that think about quite lot my first baby was born 9lb1oz 22 inches long and gave me third degree tear plus second small tear on the way out yeah thanks right with total of 28 stitches have healed up perfectly with no issues around bladder or bowel control but am afraid of delivering my second vaginally as do want to tear again has anyone else out there been in this situation if so what did you decide for your second delivery was told that have no greater risk of tearing than first time mum and that could deliver vaginally but pretty tempted to have an elective cesarean second time around edit thanks everyone for your thoughts and experiences there are other factors that had me considering my options but the tear was the major one it great to read so many stories of good experiences following bad every baby and birth is different while did tear thay badly with my first did tear changed doctors and hospitals and with the help of kick ass mid wife did tear at all with my second if you re really worried about it make sure you ask specifically about what your doctors techniques and what not are for preventing tearing as that big concern for you did tear nearly that bad with my first but did tear had my second baby sixteen years later and the doctor was estimating him upwards of ten pounds thought would tear very badly but did tear at all if you have time to be intimate with your so and you do have any worrisome medical conditions you can incorporate some massage and or stretching of the area to prepare for the birth had the same experience tore badly with first baby pounder and no tears for following all 10 pounds+ the birth practitioner makes all the difference two things can recommend support as in physically supporting your perineum and gravity birth in upright position this was the main difference between my first and subsequent births holding warm wet handtowel *down there* as you push supports the skin midwife holds one from behind being upright does half the pushing work for you so you re not straining your muscles and stretching the skin to breaking point every delivery really is different but chances are things will be easier for your second it not guarantee but it likely my first was lbs oz and had second degree tear that was very nearly 3rd degree the labor was prolonged and very intense and recovery was not fun my second was 10 lbs oz with quick easy delivery and not single tear or abrasion it was also water birth so that may have something to do with it discuss the issue with your ob midwife you can ask them to apply pressure to your perineum before during crowning and look into different birthing positions giving birth on your back actually narrows the pelvis and puts more pressure on your perineum squatting or even sitting up is much easier on your body you can also try perineal massage http www youtube com watch v=dk2p8ziqc6y but imo the most important factor is how tense relaxed you are even if you do tear it is likely to be less severe so try not to worry too much ultimately it up to you but it worth mentioning that sections while safe do have higher incidence of complications than vaginal birth good god you are champ hey we just had thread about tearing over on babybumps go check it out am only commenting about the section as had one of those after failed induction and am electing to have another if were you and am not and have no idea what vagina tear feels like so take this with grain of salt would my stomach after my section in august 2009 has still not fully repaired the muscle the outside is fine but know this sounds silly used to could hold in my gut can now but there is pooch in my lower abdomen that just ca be controlled if vaginal tear repairs itself without side effects that stay for years that is what would do am getting csection again because my tummy is already in this state but if could have avoided this whole mess would have after have this one am gon na hit the gym again as soon as am able but it long road to hoe know this is first world problem but it was something had considered prior so wanted to bring it up tl dr the section has messed up my stomach muscles so consider that possible consequence do you have other concerns with the birth besides tearing just curious because to me it does make any sense to replace the chance of tearing with surgery sections are not walk in the park and come with more risk than vaginal delivery you be trading some external tearing for cutting open your skin and uterus and displacing major abdominal muscles you ll be dealing with the effects of surgery for at least weeks after the birth if you ve already done vaginal birth it likely will be easier the second time you can stretch the area and have the doctors apply oil during crowning you can even ask your doctor about an episiotomy but planning sections seems bit drastic my daughter was the exact same size and tore pretty bad and an episiotomy on top of it to get her shoulders out with my second he was lot smaller only lbs 12 ounces and only had one very minor tear which did even need stitches even if the risk of tearing had been higher the second time would have taken the tear over section recovery deleted had surprise episiotomy my giant headed 9lb oz baby was *finally* on his way out after much cajoling and my ob just said do look and snipped the opening little wider surgical grade incision neat and tidy stitches speedy healing no fuss highly recommend episiotomies it is true that *small* tears heal quicker than incisions it impossible to judge where and how big tear will be they did the same to me they told me they were going to cut me little and did even notice them do it guess was already in so much pain did feel it then they stitched me up as nursed my baby and the adrenaline and excitement meant barely felt that either all healed up within about ten days my first born was 8lb 5oz vaginal delivery with epidural and sustained fourth degree tear and forceps were used my tear was so bad that the doctor did even bother counting the stitches luckily healed up fine with no side effects when it came time for my second to be born was strangely not worried about tearing again but made conscious decision to go without an epidural or any other pain meds because felt that part of the reason forceps were used was because was pushing incorrectly due to not being able to feel damned thing second labor had very tiny tear just few stitches and honestly do even remember any pain associated with it either during labor during sutures or postpartum so now am pregnant with number due in may and have planned again for an non medicated delivery am more afraid of how my year old will deal with the new baby than am about the delivery talk with your doctor about the risks vs rewards of delivering vaginally vs delivery via cesarean think that cesarean should only be your last option if labor does not progress properly or if there is fetal distress go for vbac having another section is only going to create another scar go for vaginal birth and skip the week recovery do give birth on your back do push while heavily medicated no seriously get out of the lithotomy position and do do purple pushing if the pain is too intense then you can have something to take the edge off but getting an epidural removes your ability to know when to push to know how much to push to know when to pause to let your skin stretch and adjust and laying flat on your back makes pushing much much harder if need to can provide you some links re elective cesarean rather small tear through skin and muscle than huge incision through multiple layers of fascia fat muscle and an organ with the risk of serious complications it major surgery never elect for major surgery if it totally optional did tear but the mention delivered on birthing stool then when started pushing she coached me through it and told me when to not push so things could stretch bit it worked did even tear little bit so it is possible to pushing go slowly could you feel what was happening during pushing did you have an epi and was it in full strength during pushing when your baby was crowning did you take break and try to breath through few contractions to allow some stretching did your care provider give your perineum support physically did they give you any oil to help the stretch all these things affect the likelihood of tear like others have said every birth is different but there *are* things you can do to try and minimize tearing and that doesn tnecessarily mean going natural one way some women have success with an
